snippet: Live fire directed into the South is being interpreted as a warning to stop the broadcasts into the North, a Cold War tactic that was recently revived.
abstract: North Korea reacts angrily to South Korea's blaring of propaganda through loudspeakers at border, promising 'strong military action' if broadcasts did not stop; both sides remain on alert for possible escalation of tensions.

byline.contributor: Dan Levin contributed reporting from Beijing, and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations.

lead_paragraph: Live fire directed into the South is being interpreted as a warning to stop the broadcasts into the North, a Cold War tactic that was recently revived.

headline.main: North and South Korea on Alert Over Loudspeakers Blaring Propaganda
headline.print_headline: Propaganda War Between Koreas Threatens to Boil Over
